answers: Claude Monet [or Oscar-Claude Monet; do NOT accept “Manet”]
parts: Name this Impressionist painter well known for his Water Lilies series, a set of depictions of his flower garden in Giverny (zhee-vair-NEE).
This other Impressionist painter painted The Absinthe Drinker and created portraits of bathers such as After the Bath.
Degas also made numerous paintings of people doing this activity, often while wearing tutus and other equipment used for ballet, a form of this activity.

answers: Russia [or the Russian Empire, or Rossiya]
parts: Name this author who also wrote The Death of Ivan Ilyich.
Tolstoy was a native of this country, which Napoleon famously attempted to invade in the winter. Other authors from this country include Fyodor Dostoyevsky and Alexander Pushkin.
The title character of this Tolstoy novel commits suicide by train. It begins by declaring "Happy families are all alike; every unhappy family is unhappy in its own way".
There are this many possible such numbers, equal to the value of 4 choose 2.
Two of the numbers, 7887 and 8778, are this kind of number which is the same written both forwards and backwards.
All six numbers must be divisible by this smallest odd prime, because any number whose digits sum to a multiple of this number, like 12 or 39, must be divisible by this number.

Name this novel set in a futuristic dystopia engineered to ensure constant happiness, with five social classes ranging from Alpha to Epsilon. Its protagonist Bernard Marx is exiled at the end of the book.
This English author wrote Brave New World. Some of his other works include The Doors of Perception and Point Counterpoint.

This real-life American industrialist is worshipped by the society of Brave New World, whose calendar counts the number of years since this man's automobile company produced its first Model T car off the assembly line.

answers: speech [or language or talking or really anything that refers to flapping your vocal cords and making sound come out of your mouth hole]
parts: Name this organ located inside the skull, the center of the body's nervous system.
This part of the brain derives its name from the Greek word for "seahorse". It is responsible for converting short-term to long-term memories, and humans contain two, one for each side of the brain.

Two other parts of the brain, Broca's area and Wernicke's (VER-nick-uh’s) area, are responsible for this ability, and damage to those areas can cause aphasia, in which they are unable to perform this ability successfully, instead producing meaningless gibberish or repeated syllables.

answers: Gallipoli campaign [accept Battle of Gallipoli; accept Battle of Çanakkale; prompt on the Dardanelles Campaign]
parts: Name this British Prime Minister who led the country during World War II. In a famous 1940 speech, he said he had nothing to offer but "blood, toil, tears, and sweat".

Churchill was a member of this political party, one of the two major British political parties along with the Labour Party. Its name indicates its center-right policy positions, and its recent prime ministers have included Theresa May.

Churchill resigned as First Lord of the Admiralty after this failed military campaign in the Dardanelles. The anniversary of the landings in this campaign is a national holiday in Australia and New Zealand.
Name these events in which tectonic plates interact, causing the release of seismic waves. They often cause the ground to shake and destroy buildings.

Earthquakes' intensity is measured by this logarithmic scale, which has largely been replaced by the moment magnitude scale. Earthquakes with a value of above 7.0 on this scale are considered "major".
This term is used to describe the point on the Earth's surface directly above where an earthquake started. It is contrasted with the hypocenter.

answers: the British Empire [or the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, or the UK, or Great Britain]
parts: Name this ethnic group, which today is the largest in South Africa. A province of South Africa is named for this ethnic group and Natal.

This early 19th century Zulu monarch developed the "bull horn" formation and a shorter style of spear as part of his massive military reformation. The expansion of his realm is argued to have triggered the Mfecane (m-fay-thaa-nay), a long period of social upheaval in southern Africa.

The Zulu Kingdom was eventually defeated by this colonial power, whose armies were also involved in the Boer Wars in South Africa. This country's colonial possessions also included Nigeria, Canada, and Australia.

answers: capitalism [accept word forms like capitalist; accept specific types of capitalism, such as free-market capitalism]
parts: In The Wealth of Nations, Smith argued that division of this term makes workers more efficient. This term, a synonym for "work", is the total human activity required to produce a good.
To illustrate the division of labor, Smith began The Wealth of Nations with an anecdote about visiting a factory for these objects, where every worker had a different job.

Smith's ideas are foundational to this economic system, in which the means of production are privately owned and operated for a profit by corporations. It is often contrasted with communism, in which the means of production are public.

answers: nitrogen [accept liquid nitrogen; prompt on N]
parts: Name this 8th planet, the farthest from the Sun, slightly more massive than its "twin", Uranus.
Neptune's largest natural satellite is this moon, which unusually orbits Neptune in the opposite direction from Neptune's rotation.
Triton's surface is mostly made up of the solid form of this element. The liquid form of this element, which boils at -320 degrees Fahrenheit, is often used as a coolant.

answers: Aboriginal people [or Aborigines; accept specific Aboriginal groups; accept but DO NOT OTHERWISE REVEAL answers like Australian Aboriginal people]
parts: Name these people whose mythology includes the giant Rainbow Serpent, who swallows the Wawalag sisters and then regurgitates them to create the land in one creation myth.

The Aboriginal people, whose groups include the Guugu Yimithirr (koo-koo yih-mih-ter), are native to this country. This landmass was colonized by British explorers who first established a settlement at what is now its largest city of Sydney.

During the colonial period, many Aboriginal groups adopted myths of a white man with this name visiting Australia and changing the social order. An actual British captain with this name made the first European landing on Australia.
Muse's "United States of Eurasia" quotes a piece by this Polish composer of many nocturnes, the Minute Waltz, and the Fantaisie-Impromptu.
Muse was also influenced by this minimalist composer of the operas Einstein on the Beach and Satyagraha.
Another of Muse's influences was Heitor Villa-Lobos, a composer from this country where he was born in Rio de Janeiro.
Name this national park, which is home to a geyser named "Old Faithful" because it erupts at regular, predictable intervals.
The majority of Yellowstone National Park is in this least-populous U.S. state, with capital at Cheyenne.
This national park directly south of Yellowstone, the other national park in Wyoming, contains part of a valley called Jackson Hole. This park shares its name with its tallest mountain.

answers: Billie Eilish [or Billie Eilish Pirate Baird O’Connell]
FIFA [accept EA Sports FIFA or FIFA 19]
parts: Name this artist known for her hits "everything i wanted" and "bad guy".
Eilish's "you should see me in a crown" was used on the soundtrack to the 2019 edition of this popular soccer video game by EA Sports. It shares its name with the world governing body for soccer.
Eilish also became the youngest person to write and perform a James Bond theme song when she was hired to produce the title track from this 2020 movie starring Daniel Craig as James Bond.
Name this co-founder of Apple who died from cancer in 2011.
Jobs was also an initial investor of this animation company, which was eventually acquired by Disney. At the beginning of this company's films, a lamp squishes the letter "I".

Jobs worked with this other Apple cofounder, who developed the Apple I ("one") and II ("two") computers. On one occasion, Jobs used this man's work to get a $5,000 bonus from Atari while only paying him $350.

answers: Battle[s] of Lexington and Concord [accept either or both underlined portions]
parts: This battle was the last of the Revolutionary War, where Lord Cornwallis was defeated by George Washington and the Count de Rochambeau.
These first two battles of the Revolutionary War were fought in towns outside Boston in 1775. Name either.
George Washington secretly crossed the Delaware River and defeated the Hessians in this battle in New Jersey which occurred the day after Christmas.

answers: linear momentum [do NOT accept or prompt on "angular momentum"]
parts: Name this quantity measured in kilograms. Weight equals this quantity multiplied by gravitational acceleration.
This vector quantity is equivalent to mass multiplied by velocity, and impulse measures the change of this quantity.
This principle named for a German scientist posits that more knowledge about a particle's position means less knowledge about its momentum and vice versa.

answers: the NAACP [or the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People]
parts: Name this event in which millions of oppressed African Americans moved North because of the South's discriminatory practices during the middle of the 20th century.

This organization promoted the Great Migration under the leadership of W. E. B. DuBois. This organization's field secretary, Medgar Evers, was murdered by Byron De La Beckwith, and its newspaper was known as The Crisis.
Medgar Evers was killed in this state, also the site of Emmett Till's murder. This state's capital lies at Jackson.
Name this Jean Craighead George book where Sam Gribley leaves the city to live self-sufficiently in a treehouse in the forest.
Sam tames a peregrine bird of this type, which he names Frightful, to hunt for him.
Sam leaves this state's largest city for its village of Delhi in its Catskill Mountains. F. Scott Fitzgerald's novel The Great Gatsby takes place on this state's Long Island.

answers: the Book of Revelation [or the Apocalypse of John; prompt on Apocalypse; do NOT accept or prompt on just “John”; do NOT accept or prompt on "Revelations" in the plural]
parts: Name this last book of the Bible. In it, seven seals are opened and seven trumpets sounded, among other visions of the end of the world.
In Revelation, the Scroll of God reveals this many horsemen of the apocalypse.
This is the last of the four horsemen of the apocalypse, and the only one to be explicitly named in Revelation. He comes on a pale horse.
